messages.messageText: Okay...first of all I loved this movie. It was worth So, this movie...The whole story is about how a psychology professor takes revenge on two police officers who destroyed his family.
Rating ?
I'd give maybe 4 out of 5. What do you think ?
Yeah! I loved the movie myself. It had the right mix. Wasn't as scary as Raatchasan, coz the villian in this movie is not actually psychic. He's got a proper reason to do the crime.
This is about revenge. Bad people paying for their past crimes. So, innocent lives are not at risk.
And also, the director did seem to keep things real. Like, I looked up the zolpidem drug that was used to hallucinate the victims. It can infact induce visual hallunications.
I loved the plot. It also kind of portrays the real helplessness of Kerala Police, if such an incident happens
I think it's a bit too unl.
Yes, but, it's hard to believe it not to be..... our whole public IT infrastructure has been in the news lately for all the wrong reasons.
Take this for eg: Govt of Kerala wbesite hacked.We are always at the receiving end.
Also, the carefree attitude with regard to trading our sensitive data with Sprinklr. And for what ?
I think we lack a proper Govt Digital policy for Govt instituitions at a national and state level...
I was really surprised to see this. Especially when there were already a lot of concerns floating around the security of Zoom app.
I was following up on that news. It looks like Govt do have an internal official video conferencing app called Vidyo
But, the thing is they are developed by some US based firm.
It just escapes me. Why don't they use some open source solution, like Jitsi
or maybe Wire
atleast you can read line by line how they work.
Being open source doesn't necessarily mean it is foolproof. Remember Heartbleed OpenSSL exploit in 2014 ?
It's still better than this though. No fun getting your account info leaked into dark web
Have you ever tried it ?
tried what ?
like getting into the dark web ?
That term confuses me. Even this chat, or any private chat could be part of dark web right ? like, who's gonna know if we discuss sale of the golden crown from Paul Barber ?
Technically yes. As long as you don't
Maybe that's how this guy hacked into Police network. Coz, in the movie they show Police having video conferencing calls using Skype.
So, it doesn't take much effort to convince the audience that the hacker is one, two steps ahead of the police.
Yeah ! I don't have a good feeling about that either.
Yeah! In the movie this guy tampers with the CCTV recordings to replace the video of his vehicle passing with some past recordings.
So, what does this guy do ? steals some sensitive data ?
but, a few things didn't make sense to me at all...like, it kinda portrays Kerala Police as some rookie when it comes to technology
like, do they really use Skype for official video conferencing ?
Why not? Skype calls are encrypted right?

Yeah! But, don't think they offer end to end encryption. Which means someone at Microsoft can still peek into the data or record every conversation if they want. And I'm not really sure how comfortable any Govt Org would be with that?
It's weird, but, I think we don't care really... :-D...Look at our defense minister having calls using Zoom app that too doesn't offer end to end encryption too.
Also, especially when Zoom app has other issues with regard to their security.
Yeah! I saw that. But, that's probably a one-off right ? I think Indian Govt uses Vidyo for official comms.
Is that end to end encrypted ?
Yeah! but, doesn't really matter too. coz, it will be hosted by Govt itself and Govt owns the data ; and not some Microsoft or Zoom.
Oh! wait a sec. The software that runs on the Govt server is developed by a US based firm, and it is closed sourced, which means we have no idea how it works or review how it works.
It still escapes me, why we are not using open source solution like Jitsi or Wire ?
Also, our Govt officials should be moving away from whatsapp and use Signal instead
They are just free, open source and fast
True. But, remember, Open source doesn't really mean it's foolproof. Remember Heartbleed OpenSSL exploit in 2014 ?
So, I maybe still happy with using Vidyo, provided they audit it properly.
Right!
Nevertheless, I don't think that's how that guy in the movie hacked the CCTV cameras. He's got no insider working for Microsoft
yeah! I think the main exploit he did was to hack CCTV camera to cover his tracks and also hack the Police network to peek on their conversation.
hurray </br> Then, Crazy Stupid love - watch this if you don't know what else to do, just like I do...
